docs.title: fn metadata.withAnnotations
docs.text:
withAnnotations(annotations)

"Annotations is an unstructured key value map stored with a resource that may be set by external tools to store and retrieve arbitrary metadata. They are not queryable and should be preserved when modifying objects. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/annotations"

docs.title: fn metadata.withAnnotationsMixin
docs.text:
withAnnotationsMixin(annotations)

"Annotations is an unstructured key value map stored with a resource that may be set by external tools to store and retrieve arbitrary metadata. They are not queryable and should be preserved when modifying objects. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/annotations"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withClusterName
docs.text:
withClusterName(clusterName)

"The name of the cluster which the object belongs to. This is used to distinguish resources with same name and namespace in different clusters. This field is not set anywhere right now and apiserver is going to ignore it if set in create or update request."

docs.title: fn metadata.withCreationTimestamp
docs.text:
withCreationTimestamp(creationTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds
docs.text:
withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds(deletionGracePeriodSeconds)

"Number of seconds allowed for this object to gracefully terminate before it will be removed from the system. Only set when deletionTimestamp is also set. May only be shortened. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionTimestamp
docs.text:
withDeletionTimestamp(deletionTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withGeneration
docs.text:
withGeneration(generation)

"A sequence number representing a specific generation of the desired state. Populated by the system. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabels
docs.text:
withLabels(labels)

"Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize (scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers and services. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels"

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabelsMixin
docs.text:
withLabelsMixin(labels)

"Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize (scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers and services. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:
withOwnerReferences(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferencesMixin
docs.text:
withOwnerReferencesMixin(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withResourceVersion
docs.text:
withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withSelfLink
docs.text:
withSelfLink(selfLink)

"SelfLink is a URL representing this object. Populated by the system. Read-only.\n\nDEPRECATED Kubernetes will stop propagating this field in 1.20 release and the field is planned to be removed in 1.21 release."

docs.title: fn metadata.withUid
docs.text:
withUid(uid)

"UID is the unique in time and space value for this object. It is typically generated by the server on successful creation of a resource and is not allowed to change on PUT operations.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: obj spec.listeners
docs.text: "Listeners declares what ports the ingress gateway should listen on, and what services to associated to those ports."

docs.title: fn spec.listeners.withPort
docs.text:
withPort(port)

"Port declares the port on which the ingress gateway should listen for traffic."

docs.title: fn spec.listeners.withProtocol
docs.text:
withProtocol(protocol)

"Protocol declares what type of traffic this listener is expected to receive. Depending on the protocol, a listener might support multiplexing services over a single port, or additional discovery chain features. The current supported values are: (tcp | http | http2 | grpc)."

docs.title: fn spec.listeners.withServices
docs.text:
withServices(services)

"Services declares the set of services to which the listener forwards traffic. \n For \"tcp\" protocol listeners, only a single service is allowed. For \"http\" listeners, multiple services can be declared."

docs.title: fn spec.listeners.withServicesMixin
docs.text:
withServicesMixin(services)

"Services declares the set of services to which the listener forwards traffic. \n For \"tcp\" protocol listeners, only a single service is allowed. For \"http\" listeners, multiple services can be declared."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: obj spec.listeners.services
docs.text: "Services declares the set of services to which the listener forwards traffic. \n For \"tcp\" protocol listeners, only a single service is allowed. For \"http\" listeners, multiple services can be declared."

docs.title: fn spec.listeners.services.withHosts
docs.text:
withHosts(hosts)

"Hosts is a list of hostnames which should be associated to this service on the defined listener. Only allowed on layer 7 protocols, this will be used to route traffic to the service by matching the Host header of the HTTP request. \n If a host is provided for a service that also has a wildcard specifier defined, the host will override the wildcard-specifier-provided \".\" domain for that listener. \n This cannot be specified when using the wildcard specifier, \"\", or when using a \"tcp\" listener."

docs.title: fn spec.listeners.services.withHostsMixin
docs.text:
withHostsMixin(hosts)

"Hosts is a list of hostnames which should be associated to this service on the defined listener. Only allowed on layer 7 protocols, this will be used to route traffic to the service by matching the Host header of the HTTP request. \n If a host is provided for a service that also has a wildcard specifier defined, the host will override the wildcard-specifier-provided \".\" domain for that listener. \n This cannot be specified when using the wildcard specifier, \"\", or when using a \"tcp\" listener."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn spec.listeners.services.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name declares the service to which traffic should be forwarded. \n This can either be a specific service, or the wildcard specifier, \"*\". If the wildcard specifier is provided, the listener must be of \"http\" protocol and means that the listener will forward traffic to all services. \n A name can be specified on multiple listeners, and will be exposed on both of the listeners."

docs.title: fn spec.listeners.services.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace is the namespace where the service is located. Namespacing is a Consul Enterprise feature."

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn spec.withConfig
docs.text:
withConfig(config)

"Config is an arbitrary map of configuration values used by Connect proxies. Any values that your proxy allows can be configured globally here. Supports JSON config values. See https://www.consul.io/docs/connect/proxies/envoy#configuration-formatting"

docs.title: fn spec.withConfigMixin
docs.text:
withConfigMixin(config)

"Config is an arbitrary map of configuration values used by Connect proxies. Any values that your proxy allows can be configured globally here. Supports JSON config values. See https://www.consul.io/docs/connect/proxies/envoy#configuration-formatting"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn spec.withMode
docs.text:
withMode(mode)

"Mode can be one of \"direct\" or \"transparent\". \"transparent\" represents that inbound and outbound application traffic is being captured and redirected through the proxy. This mode does not enable the traffic redirection itself. Instead it signals Consul to configure Envoy as if traffic is already being redirected. \"direct\" represents that the proxy's listeners must be dialed directly by the local application and other proxies. Note: This cannot be set using the CRD and should be set using annotations on the services that are part of the mesh."

docs.text: "Expose controls the default expose path configuration for Envoy."

docs.text:

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.text:
withOverrides(overrides)

docs.text: "Defaults contains default configuration for all upstreams of a given service. The name field must be empty."

docs.title: fn spec.upstreamConfig.defaults.withConnectTimeoutMs
docs.text:
withConnectTimeoutMs(connectTimeoutMs)

"ConnectTimeoutMs is the number of milliseconds to timeout making a new connection to this upstream. Defaults to 5000 (5 seconds) if not set."

docs.title: fn spec.upstreamConfig.defaults.withEnvoyClusterJSON
docs.text:
withEnvoyClusterJSON(envoyClusterJSON)

"EnvoyClusterJSON is a complete override (\"escape hatch\") for the upstream's cluster. The Connect client TLS certificate and context will be injected overriding any TLS settings present. Note: This escape hatch is NOT compatible with the discovery chain and will be ignored if a discovery chain is active."

docs.title: fn spec.upstreamConfig.defaults.withEnvoyListenerJSON
docs.text:
withEnvoyListenerJSON(envoyListenerJSON)

"EnvoyListenerJSON is a complete override (\"escape hatch\") for the upstream's listener. Note: This escape hatch is NOT compatible with the discovery chain and will be ignored if a discovery chain is active."

docs.title: fn spec.upstreamConfig.defaults.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name is only accepted within a service-defaults config entry."

docs.title: fn spec.upstreamConfig.defaults.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace is only accepted within a service-defaults config entry."

docs.title: fn spec.upstreamConfig.defaults.withPartition
docs.text:
withPartition(partition)

"Partition is only accepted within a service-defaults config entry."

docs.title: fn spec.upstreamConfig.defaults.withProtocol
docs.text:
withProtocol(protocol)

"Protocol describes the upstream's service protocol. Valid values are \"tcp\", \"http\" and \"grpc\". Anything else is treated as tcp. This enables protocol aware features like per-request metrics and connection pooling, tracing, routing etc."

docs.title: obj spec.upstreamConfig.defaults.limits
docs.text: "Limits are the set of limits that are applied to the proxy for a specific upstream of a service instance."

docs.title: fn spec.upstreamConfig.defaults.limits.withMaxConcurrentRequests
docs.text:
withMaxConcurrentRequests(maxConcurrentRequests)

"MaxConcurrentRequests is the maximum number of in-flight requests that will be allowed to the upstream cluster at a point in time. This is mostly applicable to HTTP/2 clusters since all HTTP/1.1 requests are limited by MaxConnections."

docs.title: fn spec.upstreamConfig.defaults.limits.withMaxConnections
docs.text:
withMaxConnections(maxConnections)

"MaxConnections is the maximum number of connections the local proxy can make to the upstream service."

docs.title: fn spec.upstreamConfig.defaults.limits.withMaxPendingRequests
docs.text:
withMaxPendingRequests(maxPendingRequests)

"MaxPendingRequests is the maximum number of requests that will be queued waiting for an available connection. This is mostly applicable to HTTP/1.1 clusters since all HTTP/2 requests are streamed over a single connection."

docs.title: obj spec.upstreamConfig.defaults.meshGateway

withMode(mode)

"Mode is the mode that should be used for the upstream connection. One of none, local, or remote."

docs.title: fn spec.upstreamConfig.defaults.passiveHealthCheck.withMaxFailures
docs.text:
withMaxFailures(maxFailures)

"MaxFailures is the count of consecutive failures that results in a host being removed from the pool."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

"Namespace is the namespace for the Name parameter."

docs.title: fn spec.sources.withPartition
docs.text:

"Partition is the Admin Partition for the Name parameter."

docs.title: fn spec.sources.withPermissions
docs.text:
withPermissions(permissions)

"Permissions is the list of all additional L7 attributes that extend the intention match criteria. Permission precedence is applied top to bottom. For any given request the first permission to match in the list is terminal and stops further evaluation. As with L4 intentions, traffic that fails to match any of the provided permissions in this intention will be subject to the default intention behavior is defined by the default ACL policy. This should be omitted for an L4 intention as it is mutually exclusive with the Action field."

docs.title: fn spec.sources.withPermissionsMixin
docs.text:
withPermissionsMixin(permissions)

This should be omitted for an L4 intention as it is mutually exclusive with the Action field."

"DefaultSubset is the subset to use when no explicit subset is requested. If empty the unnamed subset is used."

docs.title: fn spec.withFailover
docs.text:
withFailover(failover)

"Failover controls when and how to reroute traffic to an alternate pool of service instances. The map is keyed by the service subset it applies to and the special string \"*\" is a wildcard that applies to any subset not otherwise specified here."

docs.text:

docs.title: obj spec.loadBalancer
docs.text: "LoadBalancer determines the load balancing policy and configuration for services issuing requests to this upstream service."

docs.title: fn spec.loadBalancer.withHashPolicies
docs.text:
withHashPolicies(hashPolicies)

"HashPolicies is a list of hash policies to use for hashing load balancing algorithms. Hash policies are evaluated individually and combined such that identical lists result in the same hash. If no hash policies are present, or none are successfully evaluated, then a random backend host will be selected."

docs.title: fn spec.loadBalancer.withHashPoliciesMixin
docs.text:
withHashPoliciesMixin(hashPolicies)

"HashPolicies is a list of hash policies to use for hashing load balancing algorithms. Hash policies are evaluated individually and combined such that identical lists result in the same hash. If no hash policies are present, or none are successfully evaluated, then a random backend host will be selected."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: obj spec.loadBalancer.hashPolicies

docs.text:
withTerminal(terminal)

"Terminal will short circuit the computation of the hash when multiple hash policies are present. If a hash is computed when a Terminal policy is evaluated, then that hash will be used and subsequent hash policies will be ignored."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: obj metadata
docs.text: "ObjectMeta is metadata that all persisted resources must have, which includes all objects users must create."

docs.title: fn metadata.withAnnotations
docs.text:
withAnnotations(annotations)

"Annotations is an unstructured key value map stored with a resource that may be set by external tools to store and retrieve arbitrary metadata. They are not queryable and should be preserved when modifying objects. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/annotations"

docs.title: fn metadata.withAnnotationsMixin
docs.text:
withAnnotationsMixin(annotations)

"Annotations is an unstructured key value map stored with a resource that may be set by external tools to store and retrieve arbitrary metadata. They are not queryable and should be preserved when modifying objects. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/annotations"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withClusterName
docs.text:
withClusterName(clusterName)

"The name of the cluster which the object belongs to. This is used to distinguish resources with same name and namespace in different clusters. This field is not set anywhere right now and apiserver is going to ignore it if set in create or update request."

docs.title: fn metadata.withCreationTimestamp
docs.text:
withCreationTimestamp(creationTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds
docs.text:
withDeletionGracePeriodSeconds(deletionGracePeriodSeconds)

"Number of seconds allowed for this object to gracefully terminate before it will be removed from the system. Only set when deletionTimestamp is also set. May only be shortened. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withDeletionTimestamp
docs.text:
withDeletionTimestamp(deletionTimestamp)

"Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct marshaling to YAML and JSON. Wrappers are provided for many of the factory methods that the time package offers."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withGeneration
docs.text:
withGeneration(generation)

"A sequence number representing a specific generation of the desired state. Populated by the system. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabels
docs.text:
withLabels(labels)

"Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize (scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers and services. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels"

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabelsMixin
docs.text:
withLabelsMixin(labels)

"Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize (scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers and services. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels"

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:
withOwnerReferences(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferencesMixin
docs.text:
withOwnerReferencesMixin(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withResourceVersion
docs.text:
withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withSelfLink
docs.text:
withSelfLink(selfLink)

"SelfLink is a URL representing this object. Populated by the system. Read-only.\n\nDEPRECATED Kubernetes will stop propagating this field in 1.20 release and the field is planned to be removed in 1.21 release."

docs.title: fn metadata.withUid
docs.text:
withUid(uid)

"UID is the unique in time and space value for this object. It is typically generated by the server on successful creation of a resource and is not allowed to change on PUT operations.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids"

docs.title: obj spec
docs.text: "ServiceSplitterSpec defines the desired state of ServiceSplitter"

docs.title: fn spec.withSplits
docs.text:
withSplits(splits)

"Splits defines how much traffic to send to which set of service instances during a traffic split. The sum of weights across all splits must add up to 100."

docs.title: fn spec.withSplitsMixin
docs.text:
withSplitsMixin(splits)

"Splits defines how much traffic to send to which set of service instances during a traffic split. The sum of weights across all splits must add up to 100."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: obj spec.splits
docs.text: "Splits defines how much traffic to send to which set of service instances during a traffic split. The sum of weights across all splits must add up to 100."

docs.title: fn spec.splits.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"The namespace to resolve the service from instead of the current namespace. If empty the current namespace is assumed."

docs.title: fn spec.splits.withService
docs.text:
withService(service)

"Service is the service to resolve instead of the default."

docs.title: fn spec.splits.withServiceSubset
docs.text:
withServiceSubset(serviceSubset)

"ServiceSubset is a named subset of the given service to resolve instead of one defined as that service's DefaultSubset. If empty the default subset is used."

docs.title: fn spec.splits.withWeight
docs.text:
withWeight(weight)

"Weight is a value between 0 and 100 reflecting what portion of traffic should be directed to this split. The smallest representable weight is 1/10000 or .01%."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: obj spec.tolerations
docs.text: "Tolerations allow the scheduler to schedule nodes with matching taints. More Info: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/scheduling-eviction/taint-and-toleration/"

docs.title: fn spec.tolerations.withEffect
docs.text:
withEffect(effect)

"Effect indicates the taint effect to match. Empty means match all taint effects. When specified, allowed values are NoSchedule, PreferNoSchedule and NoExecute."

docs.title: fn spec.tolerations.withKey
docs.text:
withKey(key)

"Key is the taint key that the toleration applies to. Empty means match all taint keys. If the key is empty, operator must be Exists; this combination means to match all values and all keys."

docs.title: fn spec.tolerations.withOperator
docs.text:
withOperator(operator)

"Operator represents a key's relationship to the value. Valid operators are Exists and Equal. Defaults to Equal. Exists is equivalent to wildcard for value, so that a pod can tolerate all taints of a particular category."

docs.title: fn spec.tolerations.withTolerationSeconds
docs.text:
withTolerationSeconds(tolerationSeconds)

"TolerationSeconds represents the period of time the toleration (which must be of effect NoExecute, otherwise this field is ignored) tolerates the taint. By default, it is not set, which means tolerate the taint forever (do not evict). Zero and negative values will be treated as 0 (evict immediately) by the system."

docs.title: fn spec.tolerations.withValue
docs.text:
withValue(value)

"Value is the taint value the toleration matches to. If the operator is Exists, the value should be empty, otherwise just a regular string."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn spec.defaults.passiveHealthCheck.withBaseEjectionTime
docs.text:
withBaseEjectionTime(baseEjectionTime)

"The base time that a host is ejected for. The real time is equal to the base time multiplied by the number of times the host has been ejected and is capped by max_ejection_time (Default 300s). Defaults to 30s."

docs.title: fn spec.defaults.passiveHealthCheck.withEnforcingConsecutive5xx
docs.text:
withEnforcingConsecutive5xx(enforcingConsecutive5xx)

"EnforcingConsecutive5xx is the % chance that a host will be actually ejected when an outlier status is detected through consecutive 5xx. This setting can be used to disable ejection or to ramp it up slowly. Ex. Setting this to 10 will make it a 10% chance that the host will be ejected."

docs.title: fn spec.defaults.passiveHealthCheck.withInterval
docs.text:
withInterval(interval)

"Interval between health check analysis sweeps. Each sweep may remove hosts or return hosts to the pool. Ex. setting this to \"10s\" will set the interval to 10 seconds."

docs.title: fn spec.defaults.passiveHealthCheck.withMaxEjectionPercent
docs.text:
withMaxEjectionPercent(maxEjectionPercent)

"The maximum % of an upstream cluster that can be ejected due to outlier detection. Defaults to 10% but will eject at least one host regardless of the value."

docs.title: fn spec.defaults.passiveHealthCheck.withMaxFailures
docs.text:
withMaxFailures(maxFailures)

"MaxFailures is the count of consecutive failures that results in a host being removed from the pool."

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn spec.withAudiences
docs.text:
withAudiences(audiences)

"Audiences is the set of audiences the JWT is allowed to access. If specified, all JWTs verified with this provider must address at least one of these to be considered valid."

docs.text:
withAudiencesMixin(audiences)

docs.text:
withClockSkewSeconds(clockSkewSeconds)

"ClockSkewSeconds specifies the maximum allowable time difference from clock skew when validating the \"exp\" (Expiration) and \"nbf\" (Not Before) claims. \n Default value is 30 seconds."

docs.title: fn spec.withIssuer
docs.text:
withIssuer(issuer)

"Issuer is the entity that must have issued the JWT. This value must match the \"iss\" claim of the token."

docs.title: fn spec.withLocations
docs.text:
withLocations(locations)

"Locations where the JWT will be present in requests. Envoy will check all of these locations to extract a JWT. If no locations are specified Envoy will default to: 1. Authorization header with Bearer schema: \"Authorization: Bearer \" 2. accessToken query parameter."

docs.title: fn spec.withLocationsMixin
docs.text:

docs.title: obj spec.cacheConfig
docs.text: "CacheConfig defines configuration for caching the validation result for previously seen JWTs. Caching results can speed up verification when individual tokens are expected to be handled multiple times."

docs.title: fn spec.cacheConfig.withSize
docs.text:
withSize(size)

"Size specifies the maximum number of JWT verification results to cache. \n Defaults to 0, meaning that JWT caching is disabled."

docs.title: obj spec.forwarding
docs.text: "Forwarding defines rules for forwarding verified JWTs to the backend."

docs.title: fn spec.forwarding.withHeaderName
docs.text:
withHeaderName(headerName)

"HeaderName is a header name to use when forwarding a verified JWT to the backend. The verified JWT could have been extracted from any location (query param, header, or cookie). \n The header value will be base64-URL-encoded, and will not be padded unless PadForwardPayloadHeader is true."

docs.title: fn spec.forwarding.withPadForwardPayloadHeader
docs.text:
withPadForwardPayloadHeader(padForwardPayloadHeader)

"PadForwardPayloadHeader determines whether padding should be added to the base64 encoded token forwarded with ForwardPayloadHeader. \n Default value is false."

docs.title: obj spec.jsonWebKeySet
docs.text: "JSONWebKeySet defines a JSON Web Key Set, its location on disk, or the means with which to fetch a key set from a remote server."

docs.title: obj spec.jsonWebKeySet.local
docs.text: "Local specifies a local source for the key set."

docs.title: fn spec.jsonWebKeySet.local.withFilename
docs.text:
withFilename(filename)

"Filename configures a location on disk where the JWKS can be found. If specified, the file must be present on the disk of ALL proxies with intentions referencing this provider."

docs.title: fn spec.jsonWebKeySet.local.withJwks
docs.text:
withJwks(jwks)

"JWKS contains a base64 encoded JWKS."

docs.title: obj spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote
docs.text: "Remote specifies how to fetch a key set from a remote server."

docs.title: fn spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.withCacheDuration
docs.text:
withCacheDuration(cacheDuration)

"CacheDuration is the duration after which cached keys should be expired. \n Default value is 5 minutes."

docs.title: fn spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.withFetchAsynchronously
docs.text:
withFetchAsynchronously(fetchAsynchronously)

"FetchAsynchronously indicates that the JWKS should be fetched when a client request arrives. Client requests will be paused until the JWKS is fetched. If false, the proxy listener will wait for the JWKS to be fetched before being activated. \n Default value is false."

docs.title: fn spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.withRequestTimeoutMs
docs.text:
withRequestTimeoutMs(requestTimeoutMs)

"RequestTimeoutMs is the number of milliseconds to time out when making a request for the JWKS."

docs.title: fn spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.withUri
docs.text:
withUri(uri)

"URI is the URI of the server to query for the JWKS."

docs.title: obj spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.jwksCluster
docs.text: "JWKSCluster defines how the specified Remote JWKS URI is to be fetched."

docs.title: fn spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.jwksCluster.withConnectTimeout
docs.text:
withConnectTimeout(connectTimeout)

"The timeout for new network connections to hosts in the cluster. If not set, a default value of 5s will be used."

docs.title: fn spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.jwksCluster.withDiscoveryType
docs.text:
withDiscoveryType(discoveryType)

"DiscoveryType refers to the service discovery type to use for resolving the cluster. \n This defaults to STRICT_DNS. Other options include STATIC, LOGICAL_DNS, EDS or ORIGINAL_DST."

docs.title: obj spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.jwksCluster.tlsCertificates
docs.text: "TLSCertificates refers to the data containing certificate authority certificates to use in verifying a presented peer certificate. If not specified and a peer certificate is presented it will not be verified. \n Must be either CaCertificateProviderInstance or TrustedCA."

docs.title: obj spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.jwksCluster.tlsCertificates.caCertificateProviderInstance
docs.text: "CaCertificateProviderInstance Certificate provider instance for fetching TLS certificates."

docs.title: fn spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.jwksCluster.tlsCertificates.caCertificateProviderInstance.withCertificateName
docs.text:
withCertificateName(certificateName)

"CertificateName is used to specify certificate instances or types. For example, \"ROOTCA\" to specify a root-certificate (validation context) or \"example.com\" to specify a certificate for a particular domain. \n The default value is the empty string."

docs.title: fn spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.jwksCluster.tlsCertificates.caCertificateProviderInstance.withInstanceName
docs.text:
withInstanceName(instanceName)

"InstanceName refers to the certificate provider instance name. \n The default value is \"default\"."

docs.title: obj spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.jwksCluster.tlsCertificates.trustedCA
docs.text: "TrustedCA defines TLS certificate data containing certificate authority certificates to use in verifying a presented peer certificate. \n Exactly one of Filename, EnvironmentVariable, InlineString or InlineBytes must be specified."

docs.title: fn spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.jwksCluster.tlsCertificates.trustedCA.withEnvironmentVariable
docs.text: withEnvironmentVariable(environmentVariable)

docs.text: withFilename(filename)

docs.text: withInlineBytes(inlineBytes)

docs.text: withInlineString(inlineString)

docs.title: obj spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.retryPolicy
docs.text: "RetryPolicy defines a retry policy for fetching JWKS. \n There is no retry by default."

docs.title: fn spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.retryPolicy.withNumRetries
docs.text:
withNumRetries(numRetries)

"NumRetries is the number of times to retry fetching the JWKS. The retry strategy uses jittered exponential backoff with a base interval of 1s and max of 10s. \n Default value is 0."

docs.title: obj spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.retryPolicy.retryPolicyBackOff
docs.text: "Retry's backoff policy. \n Defaults to Envoy's backoff policy."

docs.title: fn spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.retryPolicy.retryPolicyBackOff.withBaseInterval
docs.text:
withBaseInterval(baseInterval)

"BaseInterval to be used for the next back off computation. \n The default value from envoy is 1s."

docs.title: fn spec.jsonWebKeySet.remote.retryPolicy.retryPolicyBackOff.withMaxInterval
docs.text:
withMaxInterval(maxInterval)

"MaxInternal to be used to specify the maximum interval between retries. Optional but should be greater or equal to BaseInterval. \n Defaults to 10 times BaseInterval."

docs.title: fn spec.locations.header.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name is the name of the header containing the token."

docs.title: fn spec.locations.header.withValuePrefix
docs.text:
withValuePrefix(valuePrefix)

"ValuePrefix is an optional prefix that precedes the token in the header value. For example, \"Bearer \" is a standard value prefix for a header named \"Authorization\", but the prefix is not part of the token itself: \"Authorization: Bearer \

docs.title: obj spec.locations.queryParam

docs.title: obj spec.peering
docs.text: "Peering defines the peering configuration for the service mesh."

docs.title: fn spec.peering.withPeerThroughMeshGateways
docs.text:
withPeerThroughMeshGateways(peerThroughMeshGateways)

"PeerThroughMeshGateways determines whether peering traffic between control planes should flow through mesh gateways. If enabled, Consul servers will advertise mesh gateway addresses as their own. Additionally, mesh gateways will configure themselves to expose the local servers using a peering-specific SNI."

docs.title: obj spec.tls
docs.text: "TLS defines the TLS configuration for the service mesh."

docs.title: obj spec.tls.incoming
docs.text: "Incoming defines the TLS configuration for inbound mTLS connections targeting the public listener on Connect and TerminatingGateway proxy kinds."

docs.title: fn spec.tls.incoming.withCipherSuites
docs.text:
withCipherSuites(cipherSuites)

"CipherSuites sets the default list of TLS cipher suites to support when negotiating connections using TLS 1.2 or earlier. If unspecified, Envoy will use a default server cipher list. The list of supported cipher suites can be seen in https://github.com/hashicorp/consul/blob/v1.11.2/types/tls.go#L154-L169 and is dependent on underlying support in Envoy. Future releases of Envoy may remove currently-supported but insecure cipher suites, and future releases of Consul may add new supported cipher suites if any are added to Envoy."

docs.title: fn spec.tls.incoming.withCipherSuitesMixin
docs.text:
withCipherSuitesMixin(cipherSuites)

"CipherSuites sets the default list of TLS cipher suites to support when negotiating connections using TLS 1.2 or earlier. If unspecified, Envoy will use a default server cipher list. The list of supported cipher suites can be seen in https://github.com/hashicorp/consul/blob/v1.11.2/types/tls.go#L154-L169 and is dependent on underlying support in Envoy. Future releases of Envoy may remove currently-supported but insecure cipher suites, and future releases of Consul may add new supported cipher suites if any are added to Envoy."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn spec.tls.incoming.withTlsMaxVersion
docs.text:
withTlsMaxVersion(tlsMaxVersion)

"TLSMaxVersion sets the default maximum TLS version supported. Must be greater than or equal to TLSMinVersion. One of TLS_AUTO, TLSv1_0, TLSv1_1, TLSv1_2, or TLSv1_3. If unspecified, Envoy will default to TLS 1.3 as a max version for incoming connections."

docs.title: fn spec.tls.incoming.withTlsMinVersion
docs.text:
withTlsMinVersion(tlsMinVersion)

"TLSMinVersion sets the default minimum TLS version supported. One of TLS_AUTO, TLSv1_0, TLSv1_1, TLSv1_2, or TLSv1_3. If unspecified, Envoy v1.22.0 and newer will default to TLS 1.2 as a min version, while older releases of Envoy default to TLS 1.0."

docs.title: obj spec.tls.outgoing
docs.text: "Outgoing defines the TLS configuration for outbound mTLS connections dialing upstreams from Connect and IngressGateway proxy kinds."

docs.title: fn spec.tls.outgoing.withCipherSuites
docs.text:
withCipherSuites(cipherSuites)

"CipherSuites sets the default list of TLS cipher suites to support when negotiating connections using TLS 1.2 or earlier. If unspecified, Envoy will use a default server cipher list. The list of supported cipher suites can be seen in https://github.com/hashicorp/consul/blob/v1.11.2/types/tls.go#L154-L169 and is dependent on underlying support in Envoy. Future releases of Envoy may remove currently-supported but insecure cipher suites, and future releases of Consul may add new supported cipher suites if any are added to Envoy."

docs.title: fn spec.tls.outgoing.withCipherSuitesMixin
docs.text:
withCipherSuitesMixin(cipherSuites)

"CipherSuites sets the default list of TLS cipher suites to support when negotiating connections using TLS 1.2 or earlier. If unspecified, Envoy will use a default server cipher list. The list of supported cipher suites can be seen in https://github.com/hashicorp/consul/blob/v1.11.2/types/tls.go#L154-L169 and is dependent on underlying support in Envoy. Future releases of Envoy may remove currently-supported but insecure cipher suites, and future releases of Consul may add new supported cipher suites if any are added to Envoy."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn spec.tls.outgoing.withTlsMaxVersion
docs.text:
withTlsMaxVersion(tlsMaxVersion)

"TLSMaxVersion sets the default maximum TLS version supported. Must be greater than or equal to TLSMinVersion. One of TLS_AUTO, TLSv1_0, TLSv1_1, TLSv1_2, or TLSv1_3. If unspecified, Envoy will default to TLS 1.3 as a max version for incoming connections."

docs.title: fn spec.tls.outgoing.withTlsMinVersion
docs.text:
withTlsMinVersion(tlsMinVersion)

"TLSMinVersion sets the default minimum TLS version supported. One of TLS_AUTO, TLSv1_0, TLSv1_1, TLSv1_2, or TLSv1_3. If unspecified, Envoy v1.22.0 and newer will default to TLS 1.2 as a min version, while older releases of Envoy default to TLS 1.0."

docs.title: obj spec.transparentProxy
docs.text: "TransparentProxy controls the configuration specific to proxies in \"transparent\" mode. Added in v1.10.0."

docs.title: fn spec.transparentProxy.withMeshDestinationsOnly
docs.text:
withMeshDestinationsOnly(meshDestinationsOnly)

"MeshDestinationsOnly determines whether sidecar proxies operating in \"transparent\" mode can proxy traffic to IP addresses not registered in Consul's catalog. If enabled, traffic will only be proxied to upstreams with service registrations in the catalog."

docs.title: consul.v1alpha1.meshService
docs.text: "MeshService holds a reference to an externally managed Consul Service Mesh service."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizersMixin
docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withGeneration

"A sequence number representing a specific generation of the desired state. Populated by the system. Read-only."

docs.title: fn metadata.withLabelsMixin
docs.text:
withLabelsMixin(labels)

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withName
docs.text:
withName(name)

"Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration definition. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names"

docs.title: fn metadata.withNamespace
docs.text:
withNamespace(namespace)

"Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is equivalent to the \"default\" namespace, but \"default\" is the canonical representation. Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for those objects will be empty.\n\nMust be a DNS_LABEL. Cannot be updated. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces"

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferences
docs.text:
withOwnerReferences(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

docs.title: fn metadata.withOwnerReferencesMixin
docs.text:
withOwnerReferencesMixin(ownerReferences)

"List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller, then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true. There cannot be more than one managing controller."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withResourceVersion
docs.text:
withResourceVersion(resourceVersion)

"An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources. Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server. They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. Value must be treated as opaque by clients and . More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency"

docs.title: fn metadata.withSelfLink
docs.text:
withSelfLink(selfLink)

"SelfLink is a URL representing this object. Populated by the system. Read-only.\n\nDEPRECATED Kubernetes will stop propagating this field in 1.20 release and the field is planned to be removed in 1.21 release."

docs.title: fn metadata.withUid
docs.text:
withUid(uid)

"UID is the unique in time and space value for this object. It is typically generated by the server on successful creation of a resource and is not allowed to change on PUT operations.\n\nPopulated by the system. Read-only. More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids"

docs.title: fn metadata.withFinalizers
docs.text:
withFinalizers(finalizers)

"Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries in this list can only be removed. Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order. Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

docs.text:
withFinalizersMixin(finalizers)

Order is NOT enforced because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers. finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it. If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock. Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn metadata.withGenerateName
docs.text:
withGenerateName(generateName)

"GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided. If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix. The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field, and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value unique on the server. If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header). Applied only if Name is not specified. More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency"

"EnvoyExtensions are a list of extensions to modify Envoy proxy configuration."

Note: This function appends passed data to existing values

docs.title: fn spec.withMode
docs.text:
withMode(mode)

"Mode can be one of \"direct\" or \"transparent\". \"transparent\" represents that inbound and outbound application traffic is being captured and redirected through the proxy. This mode does not enable the traffic redirection itself. Instead it signals Consul to configure Envoy as if traffic is already being redirected. \"direct\" represents that the proxy's listeners must be dialed directly by the local application and other proxies. Note: This cannot be set using the CRD and should be set using annotations on the services that are part of the mesh."

docs.title: fn spec.withMutualTLSMode
docs.text:
withMutualTLSMode(mutualTLSMode)

"MutualTLSMode controls whether mutual TLS is required for all incoming connections when transparent proxy is enabled. This can be set to \"permissive\" or \"strict\". \"strict\" is the default which requires mutual TLS for incoming connections. In the insecure \"permissive\" mode, connections to the sidecar proxy public listener port require mutual TLS, but connections to the service port do not require mutual TLS and are proxied to the application unmodified. Note: Intentions are not enforced for non-mTLS connections. To keep your services secure, we recommend using \"strict\" mode whenever possible and enabling \"permissive\" mode only when necessary."
